rationale: The segment describes viral evolution but does not contain an intensifier or comparative directly modifying a risk-adjective.
statement_text: "Influenza actually makes mutations, in the sense of making errors copying its genome, at a higher rate than a coronavirus like SARS-CoV2," said Dr. Jesse Bloom, a computational biologist who focuses on influenza viruses at the Fred Hutch Cancer Center in Seattle. These errors [in genome copying] don't always work in favor of the virus. Most of the time, viruses with errors [in genome copying] won't work or be fit enough to continue to copy and survive. But every once in a while, a random error [in genome copying] can result in a change to the virus that gives it an advantage in its environment, and that version of the virus will continue to spread and grow.

rationale: The segment discusses potential changes using neutral language; 'spread and grow' is not a high-potency verb.
